_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Extraction

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Howard Glasscock -Acid Gas Injection /HG - AGI Plant is a newly constructed facility in an area that has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, Howard Glasscock -Acid Gas Injection /HG - AGI Plant trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Howard Glasscock Acid Gas Injection Facility Description of Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:

The Howard Glasscock Acid Gas Injection Facility is located approximately 8.1 miles east of Forsan, TX. The plant is designed to remove the H2S from 5 MMSCFD of natural gas at maximum capacity. The H2S gas is removed through amine treating and injected into well on location.  The treated gas is de-hydrated and sent to sales.  No liquids from the process are stored on the location. 



General Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical-specific steps:

This facility was built in accordance with the appropriate mechanical and electrical codes for gas processing plants and is subject to OSHA's PSM program. Written programs and procedures cover all of the key elements of the PSM program and the employees are well trained in the safe operation of this facility.

Chemical-specific steps Include:

1.    Hydrocarbon Detectors; Carbon Dioxide Detectors; Hydrogen Sulfide Detectors

2.    Process Safety Relief Valves;

3.    Automated Plant Shutdown System.  The plant will be automatically shut-down should key process parameters vary from specified ranges;

4.    Manual valves to permit isolation of various portions of the process;

5.    Appropriately pla

ced portable fire extinguishers to combat incipient stage fires;

6.    Back-up generator to keep controls powered during a power failure.



Five Year Accident History:

The Howard Glasscock AGI Facility was initially started in 2014 The facility has had no accidental releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site and no offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program:

The HG AGI Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the Big Spring & Howard County Emergency Management Coordinators. The Emergency Response Plan has been posted at the plant and all employees have been trained in the actions to be taken in the event of an emergency.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

No changes to the safety program or station facilities are currently planned.
